articles.headline: The Blog Prophet of Euro Zone Doom
articles.snippet: For years, almost nobody paid attention to the alarms of Edward Hugh, a blogger who predicted that the euro zone could not survive. That is changing.
articles.abstract: For years, almost nobody paid attention to the alarms of Edward Hugh, a blogger who predicted that the euro zone could not survive. That is changing.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — For years, almost nobody paid attention to the sky-is-falling alarms of Edward Hugh, a gregarious British blogger and self-taught economist who repeatedly predicted that the euro zone could not survive.

articles.headline: Power Grows for Striking Chinese Workers
articles.snippet: As companies bow to pressure in China for higher wages and better working conditions, the cost of doing business there will probably rise.
articles.abstract: As companies bow to pressure in China for higher wages and better working conditions, the cost of doing business there will probably rise.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  China’s wage contagion continues to spread.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Whither Wall Street? Pick Your Indicator
articles.snippet: In a more volatile financial world, bankers, money managers and analysts are digging ever deeper for clues about the markets.
articles.abstract: In a more volatile financial world, bankers, money managers and analysts are digging ever deeper for clues about the markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Everyone on Wall Street watches the Dow. Guy LeBas watches the Cow.

articles.headline: A Few Steps Short on Jobs
articles.snippet: Democrats entered midterm elections with the jobless rate near 10 percent and the knowledge that they had not done all they could to bring it down.
articles.abstract: Democrats entered midterm elections with the jobless rate near 10 percent and the knowledge that they had not done all they could to bring it down.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of the political mysteries of the last year is why the White House and Congress have not been even more aggressive about trying to put people back to work.

articles.headline: Legacy for One Billionaire: Death, but No Taxes
articles.snippet: Dan L. Duncan’s heirs stand to collect billions that any other year would have gone to the Treasury.
articles.abstract: Dan L. Duncan’s heirs stand to collect billions that any other year would have gone to the Treasury.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Texas pipeline tycoon who died two months ago may become the first American billionaire allowed to pass his fortune to his children and grandchildren tax-free.

articles.headline: Stimulus Talk Yields to Calls to Cut Deficits
articles.snippet: The White House is trying to promote job growth while also hailing its attempts to wind down stimulus programs.
articles.abstract: The White House is trying to promote job growth while also hailing its attempts to wind down stimulus programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  At a moment when many economists warn that the American economic recovery is likely to be imperiled by prolonged high unemployment and slow growth, President Obama is discovering that the tools available to him last year  a big economic stimulus and action by the Federal Reserve  are both now politically untenable.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Sewell Chan

articles.headline: Fed Finding Status Quo in Bank Pay
articles.snippet: A review of 28 finance firms found many of the bonus programs that contributed to the crisis were still in place.
articles.abstract: A review of 28 finance firms found many of the bonus programs that contributed to the crisis were still in place.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators reviewing the compensation policies of major banks are finding that the industry has not adequately adjusted its pay practices to reduce risk-taking.

articles.headline: Afghanistan Strategy Focuses on Civilian Effort
articles.snippet: A push in Kandahar has evolved into a plan that puts reconstruction efforts ahead of a frontal military action.
articles.abstract: A push in Kandahar has evolved into a plan that puts reconstruction efforts ahead of a frontal military action.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  The prospect of a robust military push in Kandahar Province, which had been widely expected to begin this month, has evolved into a strategy that puts civilian reconstruction efforts first and relegates military action to a supportive role.

articles.headline: Calif. Voting Change Could Signal Big Political Shift
articles.snippet: Under Proposition 14, traditional primaries will be replaced with open elections. It is a system that supporters hoped would spread to other states.
articles.abstract: Under Proposition 14, traditional primaries will be replaced with open elections. It is a system that supporters hoped would spread to other states.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The time for tinkering is done.

articles.headline: BP Concerns Drag Down Other Stocks
articles.snippet: Pressure grew for BP to cut its dividend, shaking investors even as the Fed chief said the economy would grow at a modest pace this year.
articles.abstract: Pressure grew for BP to cut its dividend, shaking investors even as the Fed chief said the economy would grow at a modest pace this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors were shaken Wednesday by the prospect that BP might cut its dividend, pulling down the broader market.

articles.headline: U.N. Approves New Sanctions to Deter Iran
articles.snippet: A new measure takes aim at the military in another attempt to pressure Iran over its nuclear program.
articles.abstract: A new measure takes aim at the military in another attempt to pressure Iran over its nuclear program.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations Security Council leveled its fourth round of sanctions against Iran’s nuclear program on Wednesday, but the measures did little to overcome widespread doubts that they  or even the additional steps pledged by American and European officials  would accomplish the Council’s longstanding goal: halting Iran’s production of nuclear fuel.

articles.headline: Bernanke Warns of ‘Unsustainable’ Debt
articles.snippet: The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, said that “the federal budget appears to be on an unsustainable path.”
articles.abstract: The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, said that “the federal budget appears to be on an unsustainable path.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When it comes to the deficit, Ben S. Bernanke has a story, and he’s sticking to it.
